Position Summary: Position for a BCBA on the Behavior Support Team (BST) under the SEL/Student Support Services Department primarily supporting a cluster of schools within the district. Responsibilities include building capacity at the school level through training MNPS employees in implementation of evidence-based practices and behavior analytic strategies, providing behavior support through consulting, modeling and coaching of strategies across all three tiers to school staff, and conducting functional behavior assessments and/or analysis.
Education: Master's Degree  in counseling, psychology, education or related field Required
Work Experience: Experience using Excel, Powerpoint and other technology related to staff training and data analysis  Required
Essential Functions:
Provides observations of students referred to BCBA by school team, makes behavior recommendations, assists with implementation by modeling secondary interventions, provides coaching and feedback to school staff, and focuses on building capacity.
Conducts functional behavior assessments (and analyses, if warranted) utilizing direct and indirect assessments, develops behavior intervention plans, and develops safety plans, if warranted. Maintains student on caseload while monitoring data and modifying plan as indicated by data.
Develops and conducts professional development for MNPS staff on behavior analytic practices and evidence-based procedures to support all tiers within the general education setting. Professional development may also be customized to meet the needs of the individual schools.
Supports teachers in classroom management through observations, individualized consultations, modeling of strategies, and providing feedback.
Serves as an external behavior coach to schools, including those employing RTI2-B (PBIS), by attending their monthly MTSS meetings, developing data collection systems, analyzing school wide behavior data, and ensuring continuous & effective implementation of tiered strategies.
Works in conjunction with Cluster Support Teams to address student, school and district needs/priorities including social-emotional needs; attends district, quadrant, school and team meetings, as needed; completes action items as assigned.
Provides direct services to students in crisis through verbal de-escalation and maintaining their safety and the safety of others.
Collaborates with outside service providers including university and state professionals in support of research and implementation of evidence-based practices.
Complies with both MNPS and BACB standards in ethical handling and management of student data, documentation.
Maintain good standing and certification through the requirements of the BACB, complete annual renewal of certification, maintain state licensure requirements set by TN Dept of Health, and comply with the BACB’s ethical code of conduct.
Licenses and Certifications:
Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA) Upon Hire Required
 Ability to obtain TN License (LBA) within 1 Year Required
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Effective communication and collaboration as a multi-disciplinary team member.
Ability to train on behavior analytic topics within small and large group settings
Justification: Matches the Therapist KSACs, including Therapiy Techniques, Client Assessment, and Crisis Intervention.

Position Summary: The job leads the development and implementation of systems that support school-level innovation aligned to the district's career readiness goals. This role works across teams to promote operational and instructional models that integrate postsecondary and workforce preparation into the student experience. Although housed within the CCR Systems team, this role partners closely with the Director of Career Academies, as well as Counseling, Advanced Academics, and school leadership, to ensure efforts are cohesive, student-centered, and outcomes-driven. The Coordinator is responsible for supporting schools in building scalable practices that connect classroom learning with career pathways, EPSOs, and transition planning. The Coordinator of Career Readiness Frameworks ensures that career readiness is not siloed, but fully integrated into how schools prepare students for postsecondary success.
Essential Functions:
Career Readiness Systems Design: Develop and support school-level frameworks that integrate EPSOs, credential attainment, and work-based learning into the broader student experience.
School Innovation Support: Guide schools in designing and implementing innovative instructional or structural models that increase career alignment and readiness, with a focus on long-term sustainability and equity.
Strategic Collaboration: Partner with the Directors of Career Academies, Counseling and Advising, and Advanced Academics to ensure career readiness work complements other readiness systems.
Tool and Resource Development: Create resources and planning tools that help school teams design, implement, and sustain career readiness frameworks.
School Support and Communication: Maintain strong communication with school-based leadership teams and staff to ensure clarity, alignment, and progress monitoring.
Professional Learning Logistics: Support logistics and coordination of PD related to career readiness, instructional model design, or innovative school practices.
Data Collaboration: Collaborate with CCR Systems and data teams to monitor implementation of school-based career readiness strategies and support data-informed improvement.
Cross-Team Integration: Ensure alignment between school innovation efforts and district priorities around advising, pathway development, and readiness outcomes.
Justification: Advisory and framework design role; no budget control.. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Position Summary: The position supports the districtwide implementation of rigorous academic programming, including Dual Enrollment (DE), Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate (IB), Cambridge AICE, and honors courses. This role ensures that educators and school leaders have the resources, tools, and support they need to offer accessible, high-quality instruction in advanced courses. The Coordinator plays a key role in supporting the development of strong honors classes that serve as an on-ramp to Early Postsecondary Opportunities (EPSOs), and collaborates with other CCR and school-based staff to increase student participation and success in advanced academics. This position requires a collaborative, detail-oriented leader who is committed to expanding access to challenging coursework and increasing student success in advanced academic pathways. The Coordinator ensures that honors and advanced programs are implemented effectively and aligned with the district's college and career readiness goals.
Essential Functions:
Program Coordination: Maintain and manage resources that support implementation of DE, AP, IB, AICE, and honors programming, including program maps, course guidance, and aligned instructional tools.
Data and Program Monitoring Collaboration: Collaborate with CCR Systems and data staff to support monitoring of enrollment, participation, and student outcomes in advanced academics to drive continuous improvement and promote equity.
Instructional Support: Coordinate the distribution and support of curriculum resources and academic supports to help ensure consistent delivery of advanced coursework aligned with national and state expectations.
Demonstrate Proactive Leadership: Identify areas for growth or system refinement and initiate improvements without prompting; serve as a thought partner and problem-solver in advancing the vision for advanced academics across the district.
Manage Resources for Program Implementation: Collaborate with the Director of Advanced Academics to plan and manage local, grant, and other program-specific budgets to ensure timely, efficient, and impactful implementation of advanced academic programs.
School Support: Serve as a primary point of contact for advanced academics implementation questions from teachers, counselors, and school leaders. Provide timely, practical support aligned with instructional and program expectations.
Honors and EPSO Pathway Support: Support the development of strong, aligned honors pathways that prepare students for participation and success in EPSOs. Identify and promote strategies to build student confidence and readiness.
Communication and Training: Provide clear, consistent communication to school-based staff regarding timelines, program updates, assessment logistics, and professional learning opportunities.
Collaboration: Partner with the Advanced Academics Coach, Director of Advanced Academics, and Counseling staff to ensure programs are equitably implemented and well-aligned with advising and student planning systems.
Professional Learning Logistics: Support the coordination and delivery of professional development aligned to advanced academic instruction and program implementation.
Justification: Cross-program fiscal and strategic leadership. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Job Description Name: Executive Director of Counseling and Advising
Position Summary: The position leads MNPS's vision and execution of a districtwide, equity-centered counseling and advising strategy. This role ensures students receive high-quality academic, social-emotional, and postsecondary guidance by building aligned systems that support counselors, advising teams, and transition planning. The Executive Director leads the development of Tiered Transition Planning and advising practices aligned to the Portrait of a Graduate, ensuring that all students graduate with a personalized plan and the tools to pursue it. This position connects departmental efforts directly to district strategic goals around postsecondary access, equity, and student success.
Essential Functions:
Strategic Vision & Program Leadership: Set a comprehensive vision for K–12 advising and counseling that aligns with district priorities, Ready Graduate goals, and the MNPS Portrait of a Graduate.
K–12 System Design & Oversight: Design and oversee advising systems and tools that span all grade bands, with distinct attention to developmental needs and strategic postsecondary planning.
Equity-Focused Systems Development: Develop systems that proactively address advising and access gaps for historically underserved students through data-informed design and intervention.
Performance & Practice Standards: Define performance expectations for school counselors and CCR advisors; establish systems to monitor and support implementation.
Capacity Building: Lead the development and delivery of professional learning for school counselors, CCR coaches, and advising teams aligned to state and national standards.
Integrated Transition Planning: Ensure consistent implementation of Tiered Transition Planning, including the Four-Year and Beyond Plan, across all schools and grade levels.
Data-Driven Decision-Making: Use advising and transition data to identify advising trends, measure outcomes, and drive continuous improvement in postsecondary advising systems.
Cross-Functional Collaboration: Work closely with CCR directors and school leaders to embed advising strategies across advanced academics, career pathways, and instructional programming.
External Partnership Management: Represent MNPS in advising-related initiatives with postsecondary partners, scholarship organizations, and external advocacy groups.
Continuous Improvement & Innovation: Lead cycles of improvement that refine advising structures and ensure they adapt to evolving postsecondary demands.
Cross-Department Alignment: Ensure advising and counseling strategies are tightly integrated with teaching and learning, SEL, and other districtwide initiatives.
Policy & Advocacy: Monitor changes in advising and postsecondary policy, advocate for reforms that benefit MNPS students, and support alignment with state initiatives.
Resource Stewardship: Manage budgets, human capital, and external resources to ensure schools are supported in delivering consistent, high-impact advising services.
Original Job Title: Executive Director of Counseling and Advising
Justification: Leads districtwide advising vision, policies, equity systems. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

Job Description Name: Manager of Career and Industry Partnerships
Position Summary: The person in this job leads the work of connecting MNPS high schools with business, industry, and community organizations in support of the Academies of Nashville model. This role is critical in ensuring strong, sustainable partnerships that create authentic, real-world learning experiences for students aligned with their academy pathways. The Manager works closely with Academy coaches, school leaders, and the Nashville Partnership Council to identify partnership needs, develop aligned supports, and ensure consistent communication between schools and external stakeholders. This position is also responsible for executing large-scale district events such as the annual career exploration fair and partner engagement experiences that elevate and expand the reach of the Academies of Nashville. The Manager should be a relationship-driven leader who understands both the school context and the needs of external partners, and who can strategically connect the two to build powerful, real-world experiences for MNPS students.
Essential Functions:
School-Partner Relationship Building: Serve as the key connector between business/industry partners and school-based academy teams. Facilitate meaningful engagement that supports pathway-aligned experiences.
Support for Academy Coaches: Collaborate with academy coaches to understand school-level partnership needs and to ensure strategic alignment between academy themes and partner expertise.
Partnership Council Coordination: Serve as the district liaison to the Nashville Partnership Council. Facilitate regular communication, shared planning, and execution of partnership strategies that align with district priorities.
Event Planning and Execution: Lead the planning and implementation of large-scale career exploration events, including the annual career fair and business engagement events that support awareness, recruitment, and alignment.
Partner Communication and Recognition: Manage systems for onboarding, communicating with, and recognizing external partners. Ensure a consistent and professional district presence in all external engagements.
Program Alignment and Strategy: Work with the Director of Career Academies to ensure partnership work aligns with CTE programming, career-based learning initiatives, and overall college and career readiness goals.
Resource Development: Create and maintain resources, tools, and templates that support consistent, scalable, and high-quality partnership engagement practices across schools.
External Communication and Public Relations: Develop and implement communication strategies to showcase the impact and success of the Academies of Nashville using multiple media outlets, including social media, newsletters, website content, and community reports. Promote awareness and engagement through compelling storytelling and timely updates.
Original Job Title: Manager of Career and Industry Partnerships
Justification: Partnership ecosystem manager; community-facing strategic role. Heavy emphasis on multi-stakeholder coordination and facilitation.

Job Description Name: Manager of Gifted and Talented Education
Position Summary: The person in this position supports the effective implementation and continuous improvement of gifted education services across MNPS. Reporting to the Coordinator of Gifted and Talented Education, this role is responsible for mentoring and supporting the district's Gifted and Talented Teachers (GTTs), coordinating professional learning, and helping ensure alignment with national standards and district priorities. The Manager also supports school-based implementation, facilitates program development, and helps strengthen instructional practices for advanced learners. The Manager must be an experienced educator with deep knowledge of gifted education, strong collaboration skills, and a passion for supporting teachers and advancing instructional excellence for advanced learners.
Essential Functions:
Educator Support and Mentorship: Provide ongoing coaching, support, and instructional guidance to Gifted and Talented Teachers across the district.
Professional Learning: Plan and facilitate professional learning experiences that build educator capacity in identifying, serving, and challenging gifted students.
Curriculum and Instructional Support: Assist GTTs in developing differentiated instructional strategies and materials that meet the needs of diverse gifted learners.
Collaboration and Alignment: Work with the Coordinator of Gifted and Talented Education and the Director of Advanced Academics to ensure program alignment with the broader academic readiness and equity strategies.
Program Implementation Assistance: Support the implementation of GATE services at the school level by responding to educator questions, resolving instructional challenges, and promoting consistency across sites.
Resource Development: Create and disseminate tools and materials that enhance program quality and instructional delivery.
Screening and Enrichment Support: Assist with gifted screening processes and support the implementation of supplemental and enrichment opportunities, including summer programming.
Family and Community Engagement: Participate in outreach efforts and events to inform families and community stakeholders about gifted services and programming opportunities.
Original Job Title: Manager of Gifted and Talented Education
Justification: Coaches educators, supports differentiated instruction for gifted learners. Aligned with Coach KSACs.

Job Description Name: Executive Director of College and Career Readiness
Position Summary: The job leads the district's efforts to prepare all students for postsecondary success by developing, scaling, and sustaining high-quality programs, experiences, and systems. This role oversees Advanced Academics, Career & Technical Education, and the Academies of Nashville, ensuring every student has equitable access to rigorous coursework, career-aligned experiences, and personalized transition supports. The Executive Director provides strategic vision and operational oversight, collaborating with district leaders, school-based staff, and external partners to align programming with MNPS's Portrait of a Graduate and overall district goals.
Essential Functions:
Strategic Vision & Program Leadership: Establish and execute a unifying vision for college and career readiness aligned with district strategic priorities and department goals.
K–12 System Design & Oversight: Lead the development and oversight of vertically aligned systems that span elementary through high school, ensuring coherent pathways for postsecondary readiness.
Equity-Focused Systems Development: Identify barriers to access and design scalable systems that close opportunity gaps in EPSOs, advanced coursework, and career pathways.
Performance & Practice Standards: Define expectations for CCR program quality and ensure consistent implementation across schools through coaching, tools, and oversight.
Capacity Building: Support the professional growth of directors, coordinators, and school leaders to implement readiness initiatives with fidelity and impact.
Integrated Transition Planning: Partner with advising and instructional teams to embed postsecondary readiness into school schedules, student plans, and transition structures.
Data-Driven Decision-Making: Use districtwide data to identify trends, inform strategies, and drive measurable improvements in participation and success in CCR programming.
Cross-Functional Collaboration: Partner with Teaching & Learning, Counseling, and other departments to embed readiness goals into academic and advising systems.
External Partnership Management: Serve as a key liaison with postsecondary institutions, employers, nonprofit partners, and national networks supporting CCR strategy.
Continuous Improvement & Innovation: Monitor program impact, adjust strategy based on data, and lead innovation efforts to ensure offerings remain responsive and future-focused.
Cross-Department Alignment: Ensure departmental strategies are fully aligned with broader district initiatives including Ready Graduate, University MNPS, and Portrait of a Graduate.
Policy & Advocacy: Monitor relevant policy at the state and national level, influence local readiness policy, and advocate for student-centered changes that improve outcomes.
Resource Stewardship: Oversee significant personnel and program budgets and ensure effective use of resources to support equity and outcomes.
Original Job Title: Executive Director of College and Career Readiness
Justification: District-level leadership, strategy, innovation, policy. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

Position Summary: The incumbent provides leadership and operational support to ensure the AVID (Advancement Via Individual Determination) program is implemented with fidelity across MNPS schools. This role is responsible for managing systems, resources, and school-based supports that embed AVID strategies as a driver of the district's college and career readiness culture. The Coordinator works collaboratively across CCR and district teams to ensure AVID implementation aligns with advising systems, EPSO access, and equity goals. The Coordinator supports schools in using AVID to close opportunity gaps, promote rigorous instruction, and build student agency in preparation for postsecondary success. The Coordinator of AVID plays a key role in ensuring AVID is not simply a stand-alone program but an embedded system that transforms college and career readiness culture across schools. This role requires collaboration, strategic alignment, and a strong commitment to expanding opportunity through proven instructional and advising practices.
Essential Functions:
Program Oversight and Support: Coordinate and support AVID implementation across participating schools, ensuring alignment with national standards and district CCR goals.
System and Resource Management: Manage tools, templates, and planning structures that help schools integrate AVID strategies into classroom instruction, transition planning, and academic advising.
Cross-Team Collaboration: Partner with the CCR Systems team, Advanced Academics, Counseling, and school leadership to embed AVID into the broader readiness infrastructure, ensuring it complements EPSO planning and advising systems.
Professional Learning Coordination: Organize and manage logistics for AVID-related professional learning, including Summer Institute, coaching, and AVID site team development.
School Support and Communication: Serve as a primary point of contact for AVID site coordinators, school leaders, and teachers, providing regular updates, implementation support, and coaching connections.
Fidelity Monitoring and Continuous Improvement: Collaborate with CCR Systems and data teams to monitor AVID enrollment, usage, and impact. Use data to identify implementation gaps and guide improvement efforts.
Equity and Access Leadership: Support efforts to expand AVID as a tool to improve postsecondary readiness for historically underserved students, including intentional integration into advising practices.
Justification: Training and implementation, no direct fiscal ownership. While role is not as clear of a programmatic lead program and resource implementation; borderline Manager, but acceptable as Coordinator

Job Description Name: Coordinator of Career and Technical Education (CTE)
Position Summary: The role supports high-quality implementation of CTE programming across MNPS high schools by ensuring that educators and school leaders have the tools, resources, and guidance they need to offer rigorous, relevant, and accessible CTE instruction. Reporting to the Director of Career Academies, this role focuses on the day-to-day coordination of systems and supports that help schools implement CTE programs of study aligned with industry expectations, graduation requirements, and district career readiness goals. The Coordinator plays a key role in ensuring CTE programs are seamlessly integrated into each high school's academic model and contribute meaningfully to students' preparation for postsecondary success. The CTE Coordinator ensures that implementation is strong, consistent, and aligned to the broader vision of college and career readiness in MNPS.
Essential Functions:
Program Coordination: Maintain up-to-date systems and tools to support implementation of CTE programs of study, including course planning resources, program maps, and instructional guidance aligned to state expectations.
Resource and Tool Management: Coordinate the distribution and support of instructional resources, equipment management processes, and materials that ensure classroom readiness and instructional quality.
School Support: Serve as a primary point of contact for CTE-related implementation questions from teachers and school leaders. Offer timely, practical guidance aligned with program goals and instructional expectations.
Communication and Training: Manage clear, consistent communication to school-based staff regarding key deadlines, state updates, program requirements, and professional learning opportunities.
Collaboration: Work closely with the CTE Instructional Coach, Director of Career Academies, and other CCR staff to ensure programming is aligned, supported, and continuously improved.
Credentialing Support: Coordinate resources, systems, and school supports that assist students in preparing for and earning industry-recognized credentials.
Professional Learning Logistics: Support the planning and execution of professional development for CTE teachers, including logistics, materials, and follow-up resources.
Operational Alignment: Collaborate with data analysts, grants staff, and school-based teams to ensure CTE programs are functioning efficiently and aligned to state and district expectations without duplicating compliance-focused responsibilities.
Original Job Title: Coordinator of Career and Technical Education (CTE)
Justification: Program and resource implementation; borderline Manager, but acceptable as Coordinator. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Position Summary: The person in this role leads the strategic development and implementation of comprehensive school counseling and postsecondary advising systems across all MNPS schools. This role ensures that academic, social-emotional, and college and career readiness advising are delivered in a cohesive, equitable, and student-centered manner. As a key leader in the CCR department, the Director is responsible for supporting school-based counselors, managing centralized supports, and aligning all advising efforts with the district's Tiered Transition Planning framework and Ready Graduate metrics. The Director works collaboratively across departments to embed postsecondary planning into daily school experiences, ensuring every MNPS student receives timely, data-informed, and personalized guidance throughout their K–12 journey. This position calls for an experienced, equity-driven leader who can translate vision into systems that guide every student toward a purposeful and well-supported postsecondary path. The Director of Counseling and Advising is central to ensuring that MNPS students receive timely, informed, and individualized guidance that prepares them for college, career, and life.
Essential Functions:
Advising System Design: Lead the development and refinement of districtwide counseling and advising frameworks that align with national best practices, state requirements, and MNPS readiness goals.
Tiered Transition Planning Oversight: Ensure high-quality implementation of Tiered Transition Planning across all grade levels, with particular emphasis on key postsecondary transition points in grades 8, 10, and 12.
School-Based Counselor Support: Provide vision, structure, and systems that enable counselors to deliver aligned and impactful services, including tools, data protocols, scheduling support, and professional development.
Readiness Integration: Ensure advising is fully integrated with advanced academics, career pathways, EPSO participation, and other district CCR initiatives.
Professional Learning and Capacity Building: Develop and manage a districtwide professional development plan to support school counselors, college and career readiness coaches, and advising teams.
Data-Driven Improvement: Monitor key advising-related performance indicators (e.g., FAFSA, postsecondary match, EPSO access and success, transition completion) and use the data to inform continuous improvement.
Family and Community Engagement: Collaborate with the Family Engagement team and external organizations to ensure families are well-informed partners in advising processes and postsecondary planning.
Cross-Functional Collaboration: Work in close coordination with CCR directors, school leaders, and central office departments to ensure advising is embedded across school experiences and is consistently supported.
Equity Leadership: Identify gaps in access to high-quality advising and postsecondary planning resources. Design and lead targeted efforts to support historically underserved students and communities.
Team Leadership: Supervise a team of coordinators and coaches to support counseling and advising across grade levels, ensuring consistent implementation, aligned messaging, and a culture of shared accountability for student success.
Justification: Strategic oversight, school-level support, program integration. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

Position Summary: The role supports the development and maintenance of data systems that inform and advance college and career readiness efforts across MNPS. This role is responsible for collecting, organizing, analyzing, and visualizing data related to key metrics such as Early Postsecondary Opportunities (EPSOs), Ready Graduate indicators, FAFSA completion, credential attainment, and postsecondary outcomes. Working in close collaboration with the CCR Systems team, school leaders, and other district departments, the analyst helps ensure that data is accurate, timely, and actionable. This role is ideal for a detail-oriented and mission-driven data professional who can connect technical expertise with a passion for educational equity and postsecondary success.
Essential Functions:
Data System Support: Maintain and improve dashboards, trackers, and reporting tools that monitor key college and career readiness metrics.
Data Collection and Management: Collect and validate data from multiple sources, including state databases, internal systems, and external partners.
Analysis and Visualization: Analyze trends and disaggregate data to support CCR planning and program evaluation. Develop user-friendly visualizations to support data use among non-technical audiences.
Cross-Team Collaboration: Work with CCR coordinators, coaches, and directors to understand data needs and ensure tools are aligned to district strategies and school support routines.
Technical Assistance: Provide technical support to district and school staff using CCR data systems. Troubleshoot issues and deliver guidance to improve system usage.
Equity-Focused Reporting: Disaggregate and analyze data by subgroup to help identify opportunity gaps and inform targeted interventions.
Performance Monitoring: Support ongoing review of CCR implementation through participation in data reviews and the development of internal progress monitoring tools.
Collaboration with Research and IT: Coordinate with the Office of Research, Assessment, and Evaluation and the Department of Information Technology to ensure data system interoperability and reporting accuracy.
Justification: Independent data support, less cross-program leadership. Aligned with Analyst KSACs; role focused primarily on data development and reporting.

Job Description Name: Coordinator of Gifted and Talented Education
Position Summary: The incumbent is responsible for leading the districtwide implementation and continuous improvement of gifted education services in MNPS. This role ensures that the district's nearly 80 Gifted and Talented Teachers (GTTs) are supported with tools, training, and resources necessary to provide high-quality instruction to gifted learners. The Coordinator serves as the primary point of contact for all GATE-related inquiries and guidance for principals, school staff, families, and community members. In collaboration with the Director of Advanced Academics and district leadership, the Coordinator ensures compliance with state and federal mandates and promotes equitable access to gifted services across schools. This position requires a proactive, responsive, and equity-driven leader with deep knowledge of gifted education. The Coordinator ensures that all gifted learners in MNPS are identified, supported, and challenged through high-quality, consistent, and inclusive programming.
Essential Functions:
Program Implementation and Support: Coordinate the implementation of gifted education services across all grade levels in alignment with state and national standards.
School-Based Support: Serve as the primary liaison for school-based staff and principals to address questions, provide guidance, and ensure consistent implementation of GATE services.
Educator Support and Development: Support and mentor Gifted and Talented Teachers through regular communication, coaching, and resource sharing. Collaborate on professional learning design and delivery tailored to the needs of GTTs.
Communication and Engagement: Serve as the primary point of contact for families and community stakeholders regarding gifted education. Maintain clear, timely communication and support inclusive outreach.
Resource and Tool Management: Maintain and disseminate instructional tools, curriculum resources, and planning guides to support differentiated instruction for gifted learners.
Program Monitoring and Improvement: Collaborate with CCR Systems and data teams to support program tracking, identify areas for growth, and ensure equitable access to gifted services across schools.
Collaboration: Work closely with the Director of Advanced Academics, Advanced Academics Coach, and other CCR team members to ensure gifted services are well-integrated into the broader readiness framework.
Screening and Identification Coordination: Lead logistics and communication for gifted identification processes, including universal screening and placement procedures.
Special Programming Support: Support planning and execution of enrichment opportunities such as summer programming, academic competitions, and talent development initiatives.
Original Job Title: Coordinator of Gifted and Talented Education
Justification: Leads program implementation and alignment for gifted learners; strategic and instructional support role.. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Position Summary: The job plays a vital role in supporting Career and Technical Education (CTE) teachers across MNPS, with a particular focus on new and early-career educators. This role is designed to strengthen instructional quality, improve program fidelity, and support teacher development in alignment with industry standards and district readiness goals. By offering high-impact coaching and professional learning, the CTE Instructional Coach helps build teacher confidence and instructional capacity—ultimately contributing to improved student outcomes and increased CTE teacher retention across the district. The Coach should be an experienced CTE educator who is passionate about supporting teacher development, improving student readiness, and building a strong pipeline of confident, skilled CTE teachers across MNPS.
Essential Functions:
Targeted Instructional Coaching: Provide regular, job-embedded coaching to CTE teachers, with an emphasis on new teachers and those in their first three years of instruction.
Standards-Aligned Support: Help teachers implement instructional strategies aligned to CTE program of study standards, industry credentials, and workforce expectations.
Professional Learning Leadership: Design and facilitate high-quality professional development sessions focused on CTE instructional best practices, classroom management, technical skill development, and CTSO integration.
Curriculum and Resource Integration: Support educators in effectively using curriculum tools, lab resources, and technology to maximize student engagement and industry relevance.
Mentorship and Retention Support: Serve as a key support system for new and early-career CTE teachers, contributing to increased teacher retention and job satisfaction.
Instructional Planning Collaboration: Partner with teachers to develop rigorous unit and lesson plans that align with course expectations and support credential attainment.
Feedback and Reflection Cycles: Engage teachers in reflective practice through non-evaluative feedback, coaching conversations, and goal setting.
Collaboration with CCR Teams: Coordinate with the Coordinator of CTE, Director of Career Academies, and school leaders to ensure coaching efforts are aligned to school and district priorities.
Justification: Provides embedded coaching and instructional planning support for CTE programs.. Aligned with Coach KSACs.

Position Summary: The employee provides strategic and operational leadership for the Academies of Nashville and Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs across MNPS. As the district's liaison to the Tennessee Department of Education for CTE, this role ensures all CTE programming aligns with state expectations and is implemented with instructional excellence and compliance. The Director is also the public-facing leader of the nationally recognized Academies of Nashville model, serving as a connector between district strategic priorities and academy principles. The Director leads a cross-functional team and regularly engages with business, industry, and community partners to advance the district's vision for college and career readiness. This position requires a dynamic, externally facing leader who can translate complex district priorities into actionable strategies grounded in the principles of relevance, rigor, and real-world readiness. The Director of Career Academies plays a central role in ensuring MNPS students graduate with meaningful credentials and experiences that connect learning to opportunity.
Essential Functions:
Strategic Leadership and Alignment: Lead the development and implementation of a coherent vision for the Academies of Nashville and CTE that aligns to MNPS goals for postsecondary readiness and equity.
CTE Program Oversight: Ensure the quality, compliance, and instructional integrity of CTE programs of study across the district. Serve as the primary liaison with the Tennessee Department of Education on all CTE-related matters, including policy alignment, credentialing, funding, and accountability.
Academy Model Stewardship: Maintain fidelity to the core principles of the Academies of Nashville while evolving the model to meet changing district priorities and student needs. Promote consistency, innovation, and high standards across academy pathways.
Industry and Community Engagement: Represent MNPS to business, nonprofit, and civic leaders as the face of the Academies of Nashville. Build and sustain partnerships that expand student access to work-based learning, mentorships, internships, and real-world career experiences.
Cross-Departmental Collaboration: Coordinate closely with directors of Counseling, CCR Systems, and Advanced Academics to ensure that academy and CTE pathways are integrated into student advising, transition planning, and EPSO access strategies.
Equity and Access Leadership: Monitor participation and success data to identify and address gaps in access to high-quality career pathways. Lead initiatives to increase participation of underrepresented student populations in CTE and academy experiences.
Team Management and Capacity Building: Supervise coordinators and coaches responsible for CTE, workforce readiness, business partnerships, and compliance. Build a team culture grounded in collaboration, responsiveness, and continuous improvement.
System and Infrastructure Development: Oversee processes related to course offerings, budgeting, credential tracking, and facility readiness to ensure academy and CTE programming is well-resourced and operationally sound.
Justification: Leads the Academies of Nashville, supervising CTE, partnership development, and school implementation.. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

The Coordinator ensures that college access and readiness are embedded as part of a sustained, strategic effort to help every student succeed beyond high school.

College Readiness Testing Strategy: Guide strategic integration of ACT, SAT, PreACT, and PSAT into instructional planning, advising systems, and school improvement efforts. Support alignment with school and district goals for college and career readiness.
Strategic School Communication: Serve as the district’s point of contact for ACT/SAT strategy. Communicate regularly with counselors, test coordinators, and school leaders to support a systemwide plan for performance improvement.
Military Readiness Oversight: Lead district-level coordination for ASVAB readiness and promote understanding of military pathways as part of a comprehensive postsecondary readiness strategy.
Tool and Resource Development: Develop and manage access to resources, vendor partnerships, and prep tools that strengthen student readiness for college entrance exams.
Scholarship and Opportunity Alignment: Connect ACT/SAT improvement efforts to scholarship eligibility, postsecondary opportunity expansion, and the broader University MNPS strategy.
Professional Learning Logistics: Coordinate training, materials, and support for school staff involved in college readiness testing strategy, including academic leaders, counselors, and advisors.
Data Collaboration: Partner with CCR Systems and data teams to monitor student participation, performance trends, and equity gaps in college readiness testing. Use insights to inform improvements and planning.
Cross-Team Integration: Work collaboratively with Counseling, Advanced Academics, and CCR Systems to ensure testing strategies are embedded in advising, course sequencing, and transition planning.
Original Job Title: Coordinator of College Access and Academic Readiness
Justification: Advises and supports college access strategies; integrates with readiness infrastructure and student planning.. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Job Description Name: Coordinator of High School Counseling and Advising
Position Summary: The position leads the development, curation, and continuous improvement of tools, systems, and resources that enable high school counselors to deliver high-quality, student-centered services. This role ensures that high school counseling practices are aligned to the Tennessee Model for Comprehensive School Counseling, the district's Tiered Transition Planning framework, the MNPS Portrait of a Graduate, and the required Four-Year and Beyond Plan. By focusing on system design and implementation supports, the Coordinator ensures that counselors are equipped to guide students through academic planning, social-emotional development, postsecondary exploration, and transition readiness—ultimately driving the district's Transitions Focused Outcome. The Coordinator should be a systems-oriented leader with deep knowledge of high school counseling practices and a strong commitment to ensuring every student receives structured, individualized support to graduate ready for their postsecondary path.
Essential Functions:
Systems Development and Alignment: Design and maintain comprehensive systems and planning structures that support aligned, impactful high school counseling practices across all schools.
Resource and Tool Development: Curate and manage counseling resources, including lesson plans, transition guides, Four-Year and Beyond Plan tools, and advisory supports that promote postsecondary success.
Professional Learning Design: Develop and coordinate training materials and PD logistics to build high school counselor capacity in alignment with district goals, state/national standards, and readiness priorities.
Transition Planning Infrastructure: Ensure schools are equipped to implement high-quality Four-Year and Beyond Plans as the cornerstone of transition support and postsecondary advising.
Data-Informed Improvement: Collaborate with CCR data staff to monitor access, engagement, and effectiveness of high school counseling systems and support continuous improvement.
Cross-Functional Collaboration: Partner with the Counseling and Advising Director, CCR Systems team, and other CCR directors to integrate counseling and advising into broader academic, career, and postsecondary initiatives.
Communication and Dissemination: Ensure school counselors have timely access to updated tools, timelines, and communication protocols that support consistent implementation.
Original Job Title: Coordinator of High School Counseling and Advising
Justification: Advisory oversight for high school-level counseling and transition planning; non-fiscal leadership.. Demonstrates program leadership and resource allocation responsibilities, distinguishing it from Advisor roles.

Position Summary: The Manager of Research-Practice Partnerships is responsible for managing and monitoring progress in the establishment and ongoing development of the collaborative MNPS Research Practice Partnership with Vanderbilt University (Peabody College) through project management, systems development, research and communication.
Education: Doctoral Degree  Preferred
Work Experience: Experience with design-based research and evaluation research, as is experience with mixed-methods research and/or experience working with methodologically diverse teams Preferred
Essential Functions:
Managing project timelines and coordinating day-to-day partnership activities.
Supporting the design and implementation of a partnership data infrastructure, including systems for preparing and sharing data and the execution of data sharing agreement(s).
Supporting the development of a co-designed research agenda, collaborative execution of research activities, and strategic dissemination of research findings.
Supporting the selection, development, implementation and/or analysis of district surveys.
Conducting research and summarizing findings in written and oral reports, both for governmental agencies and local decision making.
Communicating with MNPS, Peabody, and community stakeholders to advance the partnership, including developing new communication channels and facilitating meetings.
Assisting the MNPS Research Review Committee in the review of Research-Practice Partnership proposals to conduct research or evaluation in the district.
Supervising MNPS-based partnership staff (e.g. data analysts).
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Outstanding skills and background in project management and research design.
Familiarity with relevant laws and regulations regarding conducting research in schools (e.g. FERPA, PPRA) and demonstrated commitment to protecting student privacy. Ability to supervise a small team.
Excellent oral and written communication skills and ability to manage and prioritize multiple tasks are required.
The candidate should be competent with data management and statistical analysis software (preferably SPSS).
Justification: Matches the Coordinator KSACs, including Project Management, Task Delegation, and Resource Allocation.

Position Summary: The rolents supports the effective and compliant implementation of college and career readiness initiatives by monitoring grant requirements, managing reporting processes, and ensuring alignment to local, state, and federal regulations. This role plays a critical function in supporting the district's Career and Technical Education (CTE) program, with a primary focus on Perkins V compliance, while also supporting other CCR-related grants and initiatives. The analyst must be highly skilled in collecting, managing, and analyzing data to support program fidelity, track outcomes, and inform decision-making. This Analyst should be a detail-oriented, analytical professional who can manage complex data and compliance processes while supporting the district's broader vision for equity, access, and student readiness.
Essential Functions:
Grant Compliance Oversight: Ensure district compliance with Perkins V and other relevant grant requirements, including programmatic, fiscal, and reporting components.
Data Collection and Management: Gather, organize, and validate data related to student enrollment, program participation, credential attainment, and other key indicators. Work with CCR data and systems teams to ensure accurate and timely reporting.
Monitoring and Documentation: Develop and maintain tracking tools and documentation systems that demonstrate program implementation and compliance.
Reporting and Submission: Prepare and submit required reports for state and federal entities. Ensure accuracy, alignment, and timeliness in collaboration with CCR leadership and district grant offices.
Cross-Functional Collaboration: Work closely with the Director of Career Academies, CTE Coordinator, CCR Systems team, and other relevant departments to align data practices and grant-funded initiatives.
Audit and Monitoring Support: Prepare documentation and support district readiness for state and federal audits, reviews, or technical assistance visits.
Funding Alignment and Impact Support: Assist in evaluating the effectiveness of grant-funded initiatives and ensure that investments align with intended CCR outcomes.
Technical Assistance: Serve as a resource to school-based and central office teams on compliance expectations, allowable use of funds, and documentation protocols.
Justification: Grant compliance and tracking; solid Level II. Aligned with Analyst KSACs; role focused primarily on data development and reporting.

Position Summary: The Coordinator of Advanced Academics supports the districtwide implementation of rigorous academic programming, including Dual Enrollment (DE), Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate (IB), Cambridge AICE, and honors courses. This role ensures that educators and school leaders have the resources, tools, and support they need to offer accessible, high-quality instruction in advanced courses. The Coordinator plays a key role in supporting the development of strong honors classes that serve as an on-ramp to Early Postsecondary Opportunities (EPSOs), and collaborates with other CCR and school-based staff to increase student participation and success in advanced academics. This position requires a collaborative, detail-oriented leader who is committed to expanding access to challenging coursework and increasing student success in advanced academic pathways. The Coordinator ensures that honors and advanced programs are implemented effectively and aligned with the district's college and career readiness goals.
Education: Bachelor's Degree from an accredited institution of higher learning Required
Work Experience: A preferred candidate will have multiple program knowledge
Essential Functions:
Program Coordination: Maintain and manage resources that support implementation of DE, AP, IB, AICE, and honors programming, including program maps, course guidance, and aligned instructional tools.
Data and Program Monitoring Collaboration: Collaborate with CCR Systems and data staff to support monitoring of enrollment, participation, and student outcomes in advanced academics to drive continuous improvement and promote equity.
Instructional Support: Coordinate the distribution and support of curriculum resources and academic supports to help ensure consistent delivery of advanced coursework aligned with national and state expectations.
Demonstrate Proactive Leadership: Identify areas for growth or system refinement and initiate improvements without prompting; serve as a thought partner and problem-solver in advancing the vision for advanced academics across the district.
Manage Resources for Program Implementation: Collaborate with the Director of Advanced Academics to plan and manage local, grant, and other program-specific budgets to ensure timely, efficient, and impactful implementation of advanced academic programs.
School Support: Serve as a primary point of contact for advanced academics implementation questions from teachers, counselors, and school leaders. Provide timely, practical support aligned with instructional and program expectations.
Honors and EPSO Pathway Support: Support the development of strong, aligned honors pathways that prepare students for participation and success in EPSOs. Identify and promote strategies to build student confidence and readiness.
Communication and Training: Provide clear, consistent communication to school-based staff regarding timelines, program updates, assessment logistics, and professional learning opportunities.
Collaboration: Partner with the Advanced Academics Coach, Director of Advanced Academics, and Counseling staff to ensure programs are equitably implemented and well-aligned with advising and student planning systems.
Professional Learning Logistics: Support the coordination and delivery of professional development aligned to advanced academic instruction and program implementation.
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Microsoft office, Excel Medium
Project management Medium
Resource allocation Medium
Communication High
Problem-Solving High
Strategic Planning Medium
Adaptability High
Critical Thinking High
Justification: Matches the KSACs for Coordinator, including Project Management, Task Delegation, Team Coordination, and Budget Management.

Position Summary: The Music Therapist provides music therapy sessions to assigned students, utilizing clinical and evidence-based assessments and music interventions to accomplish individualized goals. The Music therapist completes consultations, assessments, treatment plans and session plans with developmental and academic standards in place.
Education: Master's Degree or additional degrees in music therapy, special education or related field  Preferred
Work Experience: 1-3 years school system music therapy experience  Preferred
Essential Functions:
Travels daily to assigned schools to deliver music therapy services to specific students as outlined in their IEPs.
Maintains and provides daily documentation through data within domain areas in the IEP.
Promotes a positive classroom environment through well delivered therapeutic interventions.
Provides music therapy to students as outlined in eligible studentsâ€™ Individual Education Programs.
Participates in IEP meetings and suggests if student is eligible for music therapy based on data and collaboration with IEP team members.
Maintains up to date record keeping documenting progress on IEP goals and updates IEP goals and progress reports as required.
Collaborates with school teams regarding individual needs of students that the music therapist serves in addition with consulting with school teams for those students who do not have music therapy as a service.
Maintains a schedule to ensure all students are receiving services.
Provides professional learning to other educators and classroom support throughout the district.
Licenses and Certifications:
Valid certification from the Certification Board for Music Therapists. MTBC (Music Therapist-Board Certified)  Required
Teaching Certification/License Instrumental/General Music K-12 or Vocal/General Music K-12 endorsement  Required
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Written and oral communication.
Classroom management skills.
Excellent organizational skills.
Knowledge of and ability to use various computer programs such as word processing, database, spreadsheet, calendar and email, and current music programs.

Position Summary: The Specialist Professional Learning will play a role in enhancing professional growth for teachers and district staff. This position involves managing and supporting the professional learning management system, utilizing data to drive continuous improvements, and collaborating on a multi-year induction process for beginning teachers. The Specialist will also lead and support various department initiatives aimed at instructional and leadership development.
Education:
Bachelor's Degree in education, curriculum development, or related field from an accredited institution Required
Master's Degree with certification in educational leadership Preferred
Work Experience: 3 years of related instructional and professional development experiences Required
Essential Functions:
Under guidance from the Professional Learning and Growth Coordinator, develop, facilitate, and support professional learning systems and professional learning for instructional and leadership development.
Collaborate with district stakeholders along with community partners to develop systems and professional learning for new teachers, teacher mentors, and teacher mentees.
Delivers innovative, research-based, and job-embedded learning opportunities, and implements the district-wide initiative for induction and mentoring to supports school-based leaders in the ongoing development and effectiveness of a multi-year induction program.
Utilizes Learning Management Systems to support Professional Learning Communities across the district, zone, and schools. Support the implementation and maintenance of the professional learning management system. Analyze data from the system to identify areas for improvement and drive continuous enhancements. Provide technical assistance on utilizing data to drive professional learning planning at the school and district levels.
Collaborate on the design and execution of a comprehensive multi-year induction program for new teachers. Co-lead induction sessions, providing guidance and support to ensure successful integration into the teaching environment.
Plan the delivery structure for content and support for school and district teams on topics within the scope of the work. Provide professional learning for school/district teams (leveraging the distributive leadership model) to maximize the professional learning experiences of staff.
Develop and communicate protocols and procedures for data-based decision-making at the district and school level; provide technical assistance on utilizing data to drive professional learning planning at the school and district levels.
Participate in professional development opportunities and coordinate and facilitate district-level professional development offerings.
Maintain a collection of professional materials related to high-quality professional development and reflective of current research.
Licenses and Certifications: Teaching Certification/License TN State Teaching Licensure issued by the Tennessee Department of Education Upon Hire Required
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Professional Learning Expertise
Research Skills
Analytical Thinking
Problem-solving Skills
Excellent Communication, both verbal and oral
Time Management
Adaptability
Attention to Detail
Collaboration
Leadership
Ability to build positive relationships with educators and stakeholders.
Justification: Potential for Advisor to match as well, but matches the current standards of a Coach better, building professional learning in schools using Coach KSACs such as 'Academic and Pedagogical Expertise' and 'Learning Strategies and Techniques'.

Education: Bachelor's Degree (M.S. preferred) in business, accounting, finance, hospitality or food and nutrition field Required
Work Experience: Experience in USDA Child Nutrition Procurement and local government contracts (bid and RFP) process a plus  Preferred
Essential Functions:
Keeps the Executive Director of Nutrition Services informed of all fiduciary issues concerning the MNPS Nutrition Services Department.
Reviews all MNPS Nutrition Services functions and programs.
Supervises and directs support staff in these area as needed; Finance, purchasing, bids and contracts, accounts payable, accounts receivable, and budget towards the completion of assigned duties in a timely manner.
Prepares and analyzes the Nutrition Services Operating Budget while making recommendations for improvement.
Overseas and insures the accuracy of all USDA/State claims, documents, etc. are submitted in a timely manner in accordance to federal and state regulations.
Reviews and maintains USDA regulations and directives regarding allowable spending, policy and compliance.
Screens and hires applicants for Business Support positions.
Plans and conducts periodic finance training sessions for business support employees, supervisors, cafÃ© management, etc.

Works collaboratively with Metro Nashville Gov Finance and MNPS Finance Divisions towards addressing financial issues and determining solutions
Perform other duties as assigned by Executive Director of Nutrition Services.
Licenses and Certifications: Certifications pertaining to business, accounting and food nutrition are valued  Required
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities: Knowledge of USDA regulations regarding Child Nutrition Fiscal reporting preferred.
Justification: Matches the KSACs of Specialist role, but specifically notes supervisory duties, placing this as a Specialist Lead, or the equivlant of a Specialist III.

Job Description Name: Coordinator of Workforce Readiness and Internships
Position Summary: The individual in this position leads the development and expansion of high-quality, student-centered career-based learning experiences aligned to MNPS career pathways and the Academies of Nashville model. This role ensures that all students—especially those in Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs—have access to relevant, meaningful experiences that connect classroom learning to career interests. The Coordinator supports schools in planning and executing structured experiences such as internships, job shadows, pre-apprenticeships, and career immersion events, and develops systems that make these opportunities scalable and sustainable across the district. This role requires a systems-minded, collaborative leader who believes all students should have access to meaningful experiences that prepare them for the workforce and postsecondary success. The Coordinator ensures career-based learning is not an add-on, but an integral part of how MNPS students connect their education to their future goals.
Essential Functions:
Career-Based Learning Program Coordination: Manage systems and tools to support consistent, high-quality implementation of career-based learning across high schools. Ensure alignment with state standards, district goals, and CTE pathways.
Partnership Development: Cultivate and maintain partnerships with employers, postsecondary institutions, and community organizations to create meaningful opportunities for students to engage with professionals and work environments aligned to their career interests.
Career Experience System Building: Design and support scalable systems that connect students to real-world learning experiences aligned to their academic coursework and career pathway.
Employer Engagement: Collaborate with business partners to ensure appropriate onboarding, training, and sustained engagement in career-based learning initiatives. Serve as a central point of contact for employer support.
Credentialing and Postsecondary Alignment: Support student access to opportunities that may lead to credentials, dual enrollment, or other postsecondary transitions through work-connected learning experiences.
Communication and Support: Provide tools, communication protocols, and implementation guidance for school-based career-based learning teams, academy coaches, and pathway teachers.
Professional Learning Logistics: Support the organization and delivery of professional development focused on career-based learning implementation and industry engagement.
Data and Impact Collaboration: Work collaboratively with CCR Systems and data staff to monitor participation trends, partner feedback, and program impact in order to inform strategic improvements and ensure equitable access.
Cross-Team Coordination: Collaborate with CCR directors, Counseling, Career Academies, and Advanced Academics to ensure career-based learning is integrated into advising, scheduling, and program planning.
Original Job Title: Coordinator of Workforce Readiness and Internships
Justification: Implements and manages career-based learning programs; works across schools and community partners.. Heavy emphasis on multi-stakeholder coordination and facilitation.

Position Summary: The positions leads the district's strategy to ensure equitable access to rigorous academic programs that prepare students for postsecondary success. This role oversees the implementation, expansion, and continuous improvement of Advanced Placement (AP), International Baccalaureate (IB), Cambridge AICE, and Gifted and Talented Education (GATE) programs across MNPS. The Director ensures these programs are embedded within a broader system that includes robust honors pathways and integrated AVID strategies to support students in accessing, completing, and succeeding in early postsecondary opportunities (EPSOs). The Director plays a key leadership role in improving Ready Graduate outcomes by developing high-quality, vertically aligned advanced academic experiences from middle through high school.
Essential Functions:
Strategic Program Leadership: Design and implement a districtwide vision for advanced academics that expands EPSO access, improves completion and success rates, and directly supports Ready Graduate outcomes.
Vertical Alignment of Honors Pathways: Strengthen and expand honors programming in middle and high schools to build rigorous, developmentally appropriate pathways that prepare students for advanced coursework and college readiness.
Program Oversight and Fidelity: Oversee implementation of AP, IB, AICE, and GATE programming to ensure alignment with national standards, equity goals, and instructional excellence.
Data-Driven Improvement: Monitor enrollment, performance, and access data to identify gaps, guide interventions, and track program impact on student outcomes, including EPSO completion and Ready Graduate rates.
Access and Equity Expansion: Lead initiatives to increase participation of historically underrepresented student groups in advanced academic programs through targeted outreach, scheduling practices, and support structures.
Professional Learning and Capacity Building: Develop and oversee professional learning plans that equip teachers, counselors, and school leaders to implement advanced academics effectively and equitably.
Cross-Departmental Integration: Collaborate with directors of Counseling, CCR Systems, and Career Academies to ensure advanced academic offerings are integrated into advising, transition planning, and college/career readiness systems.
Family and Community Engagement: Partner with families and community stakeholders to increase awareness of program benefits, entry points, and student supports.
Leadership and Team Management: Supervise program coordinators and instructional coaches; foster a collaborative team culture focused on continuous improvement and student success.
Justification: Oversees AP/IB/DE pathways and staff; integrates with CCR strategy, equity, and performance data.. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

Position Summary: The Department of Research, Assessment, and Evaluation is dedicated to supporting Metro Nashville Public Schools in implementing data-informed and evidence-based policy and practice. The Data Analyst plays a critical role in supporting the department's Research and Evaluation team with cleaning, documenting, analyzing, and reporting on quantitative student, employee, and school data. The Data Analyst will spend a majority of their time working with large, complex data sets.
Education: Master's Degree in relevant field Required
Work Experience:
Minimum of two years’ experience (including coursework) cleaning or analyzing data Required
 Experience with data management  Required
 The candidate should demonstrate a strong track record and interest in working with quantitative data.
 Experience working in public education and/or with education data Preferred
Essential Functions:
Prepare data and/or analyses in support of the department’s research and evaluation agenda, its assessment functions, and its accountability functions.
Independently produce critical reports and data for local, state, and federal reporting.
Create custom datasets for internal and external stakeholders.
Fulfill internal and external requests for aggregate data, such as public records requests, in a timely manner.
Produce clear written summaries (e.g. reports, briefs, one-pagers, and slides) of data and/or analyses for non-technical audiences.
Support colleagues and others with understanding and interpreting complex data.
Support the department with conducting quality assurance of data and reports.
Design clear and compelling data visualizations and/or interactive data dashboards.
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
The Data Analyst must be comfortable writing code to clean and analyze large, complex data sets 
using statistical software, e.g. SPSS (preferred), Stata, R, SQL, or Python.
Familiarity with Excel (including macros) and Power BI (or similar software) is a plus.
Superior attention to detail is essential.
The ideal candidate will be a self-starter with strong communication skills.
Justification: Matches the Analyst KSACs the best, including Data Analysis, Analytical Thinking, and Attention to detail. Given the increased scope, I'd slot this position as borderline, between II and III

Position Summary: Serves as a member of the Social and Emotional Learning Leadership Team and on various district level committees. Supervises and directs BCBAs on Behavior Support Team in providing consultation and training to teachers, parents, related service providers, and other school professionals. Provides evaluation of staff. Collaborates with outside service providers.
Education: Master's Degree in Behavior Analysis, Psychology, Education or related field Required
Work Experience: Current BCBA certification and Tennessee licensure as a Behavior Analyst  Required
Essential Functions:
Oversees the cluster referral process for behavior analysts.
Evaluates Behavior Support Team protocols and procedures, and staff effectiveness.
Develops and conducts professional development for individual schools, staff and district-wide.
Develops materials (including protocols, service summaries, and overviews of behavior supports) to support school personnel.
Provides individual case management coaching to staff.
Works in conjunction with other MNPS leadership to address student, school and district needs/priorities.
Develops data collection systems in collaboration with school and district personnel to track behavior and academic progress.
Keeps abreast of best practices and changes in Federal, State and Local laws and BACB/Tennessee LBA requirements. Makes recommended changes based on best practices.
Licenses and Certifications: Current Board Certified Behavior Analyst (BCBA certification) and Tennessee Licensed Behavior Analyst (LBA)  Required
Justification: Matches the KSACs for Coordinator, including Project Management, Task Delegation, Team Coordination, and Budget Management.

Job Description Name: Director, College and Career Readiness Systems
Position Summary: The position serves as the strategic connector across all readiness programs in MNPS, driving coherence, efficiency, and alignment in how college and career readiness is executed across schools and departments. This role leads the design and refinement of cross-functional systems that integrate CCR programming, advising practices, data tools, and continuous improvement structures. As the architect of readiness infrastructure, the Director ensures that all students are supported by well-aligned systems—from AVID to dual enrollment to transition planning—that collectively improve postsecondary outcomes and Ready Graduate performance. The Director supervises a cross-functional team responsible for CCR data, college access, AVID, and career readiness systems and serves as a strategic partner to other directors and executive leaders. This position requires a systems-oriented, strategic leader with deep expertise in operational design, data strategy, and collaborative leadership. The Director of CCR Systems ensures that every readiness program, data source, and advising structure functions as part of a seamless ecosystem that equips all MNPS students for life after graduation.
Essential Functions:
System Design and Integration: Lead the creation and refinement of integrated systems that connect CCR programs (e.g., AVID, EPSOs, career experiences) with advising tools, student planning structures, and transition supports. Ensure these systems are intuitive, equitable, and scalable.
Strategic Coordination: Act as the central coordination point between the CCR department’s directors to align programming, advising, data, and instructional supports. Facilitate collaboration and eliminate duplication across teams.
Data Infrastructure and Decision Support: Oversee the development of CCR data dashboards, reports, and performance tracking systems that drive informed decision-making at the school and district levels. Use data to identify gaps, monitor fidelity, and improve access to CCR programming.
Readiness Systems Improvement: Establish frameworks and protocols that support high-quality implementation of initiatives such as AVID, Ready Graduate tracking, and innovative readiness models. Lead cycles of improvement based on user feedback and outcome data.
Postsecondary Readiness Integration: Ensure that CCR programs are operationally integrated into the district’s Tiered Transition Planning framework and college and career advising systems. Collaborate closely with Counseling and Advanced Academics to embed these systems in student experiences.
Innovation Leadership: Identify, test, and scale new approaches to readiness that improve access to credentials, dual enrollment, work-based learning, and other EPSOs. Lead the internal development and operationalization of tools and processes that support innovation.
Team Management: Supervise a team of coordinators and analysts supporting AVID, CCR data, college access, and career readiness frameworks. Build a collaborative, forward-thinking team culture focused on equitable student outcomes.
Cross-Department Collaboration: Partner with IT, Research and Evaluation, school leadership, and postsecondary institutions to ensure systems are interoperable and aligned with both district priorities and community needs.
Original Job Title: Director, College and Career Readiness Systems
Justification: Cross-department system architecture and improvement. Demonstrates strategic leadership, project oversight, and team management responsibilities.

Position Summary: The Senior Account Clerk is responsible for providing financial, administrative and clerical services to the department. This includes opening department mail, data entry, triaging invoices for processing, manning the accounts payable mailbox by printing invoices and responding to inquiries of payment status to ensure timely feedback to vendors, employees, and stakeholders.
Education: Any combination of education and experience equivalent to graduation from high school and three years varied and increasingly responsible experience in keeping or reviewing financial records Preferred
Essential Functions:
Open department mail and distribute daily.
Sort, date stamp, and distribute invoices for the accounts payable workflow process.
Handle the accounts payable electronic mail box which has a huge influx of activities.
Respond to accounts payable inquiries via email and phone calls.
Perform data entry into Microsoft Access Database.
Manage short vendor forms for approval.
Procure department orders and cover department phones as needed.
Perform other clerical duties as assigned.
Knowledge, Skills and Abilities:
Ability to maintain confidentiality concerning financial files; excellent interpersonal skills; team player; effective verbal and listening, communications skills; demonstrate sound work ethics; respectful, honest and trustworthy.
Ability to perform office work with speed and accuracy, establish and maintain effective working relationships, great customer service, and Knowledge of departmental accounting methods and procedures; practices and terminology used in fiscal record keeping work.
Justification: Matches the Clerk KSACs, including Data Entry, Computer Skills, and Customer Service. Position has no real span of control, minimal scope that only affects the work unit, and performs semi-routine work, placing it at a level I.

Position Summary: Responsible for analysis and technical design related to helping customers solve complex challenges. Identify and qualify opportunities for improving processes.  Provides leadership and analysis related to enterprise architecture.  Supports the architecture roadmap by providing solutions that drive business improvement. Communicates best practices to team members and leadership effectively.
Education: Bachelor's Degree In Information Technology or related field Preferred
Work Experience: 1-3 years Related IT discipline (software development, networking, or database development) Required
Essential Functions:
Analyze data and data models to solve business challenges effectively and efficiently.
Evaluate proposed changes and communicate to stakeholders on the potential impact of solutions being considered.
Understand how to effectively and efficiently re-engineer business processes.
Design future state solutions to current state architecture
Understand technology trends and practical application of how to integrate into business assets.
Analyze the business/IT environment to detect and solve opportunities for improvement.
Consult with application developers on software development best practices.
Document all solution architecture work as artifacts.

Must be able to diagnose and solve problems effectively
